melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

text: ਸੁਣਿ ਸੁਣਿ ਬੂਝੈ ਮਾਨੈ ਨਾਉ ॥ ਤਾ ਕੈ ਸਦ ਬਲਿਹਾਰੈ ਜਾਉ ॥

translation.text: I am forever a sacrifice to the one who listens and hears, who understands and believes in the Name.

transliteration.text: sun sun būjhai mānai nāu . tā kai sad balihārai jāu .

melody.description: Gauri Dakhani has a similar nature to Gauri; however, the South Indian style of this Raag, including the taal (rhythm) highlights the strict and disciplined aspect of Gauri.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: When the Lord Himself leads us astray, there is no other place of rest for us to find.

melody.description: Gauri Dakhani has a similar nature to Gauri; however, the South Indian style of this Raag, including the taal (rhythm) highlights the strict and disciplined aspect of Gauri.

translation.text: You impart understanding, and You unite us in Your Union. ||1||

melody.description: Gauri Dakhani has a similar nature to Gauri; however, the South Indian style of this Raag, including the taal (rhythm) highlights the strict and disciplined aspect of Gauri.

translation.text: I obtain the Naam, which shall go along with me in the end.

text: ਬਿਨੁ ਨਾਵੈ ਬਾਧੀ ਸਭ ਕਾਲਿ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥

translation.text: Without the Name, all are held in the grip of Death. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: bin nāvai bādhī sabh kāl .1. rahāu .

melody.description: Gauri Dakhani has a similar nature to Gauri; however, the South Indian style of this Raag, including the taal (rhythm) highlights the strict and disciplined aspect of Gauri.

translation.text: My farming and my trading are by the Support of the Name.

translation.text: This is the true mark of wisdom: that one remains detached, like the water-lily, or the lotus upon the water.

translation.text: Attuned to the Word of the Shabad, one becomes sweet, like the juice of the sugar cane. ||3||
